text: Why did the contractor bring a ladder to the meeting? To take the discussion to the next level.
Estimators don’t age — they just adjust their rates.
Safety first, coffee second, deadlines third.
If duct tape can’t fix it, try more duct tape.
Client: ‘Can you finish early?’ Contractor: ‘Sure, if you pay early.’

Why did the contractor break up with his level?
Because she just couldn’t stay on the same plane anymore.
Why did the contractor bring a ladder to the meeting? To take the discussion to the next level.
Estimators don’t age — they just adjust their rates.
Safety first, coffee second, deadlines third.
If duct tape can’t fix it, try more duct tape.
Client: 'Can you finish early?' Contractor: 'Sure, if you pay early.'
Why do builders love math? Because they always work out the angles.
Estimators know the price of everything and the value of nothing — except coffee.
Why did the hammer break up with the nail? It was tired of being pushed around.
Field workers’ favorite workout? Carrying the boss’s attitude up three flights of stairs.
Client: 'Can we make it bigger?' Contractor: 'Sure, but your wallet will need to grow too.'
Why was the blueprint sad? Because it had too many lines and no friends.
Estimators’ diet: 90% coffee, 10% deadline panic.
Why do field crews always carry a pencil? In case they need to draw their own conclusions.
Client: 'Can you make it look modern?' Contractor: 'Do you mean more expensive?'
Why don’t construction workers play hide and seek? Because good luck hiding with a jackhammer.
Estimators are proof that patience is cheaper than mistakes.
Why did the crane get promoted? It always had a lifting attitude.
Field life motto: Measure twice, complain once.
Client: 'Can you add a swimming pool?' Contractor: 'Sure, just right over the budget line.'
Why did the brick break up with the wall? Too many layers of drama.
Estimators: turning coffee into spreadsheets since forever.
Field workers don’t sweat — they glisten with productivity.
Client: 'We want it cheaper.' Contractor: 'Do you want it done too?'
Why did the hammer go to therapy? It couldn’t handle being struck constantly.
Estimators: the only people who can make numbers cry.
Field crew logic: If it fits, it ships. If not, call the engineer.
Client: 'Can you make it eco-friendly?' Contractor: 'Sure, for a green fee.'
Why was the saw always calm? Because it knew how to cut through problems.
Estimators have a sixth sense — spotting hidden costs everywhere.
Field motto: Hard hats, harder work, hardest jokes.
Client: 'We need it yesterday.' Contractor: 'I left my time machine in the truck.'
Why did the nail refuse to hang out? It felt hammered enough already.
Estimators: balancing optimism with reality, one bid at a time.
Field workers know the true meaning of 'on-site entertainment.'
Client: 'Can you make it look effortless?' Contractor: 'Effortless cost included separately.'
Why do bricks make terrible comedians? They always deliver flat punchlines.
Estimators’ favorite workout: lifting heavy spreadsheets.
Field life: where every problem can be solved with duct tape or coffee.
Client: 'Can we skip approvals?' Contractor: 'Sure, skip your chance at sanity too.'
Why did the scaffolding blush? Because it saw the worker’s plans.
Estimators: turning chaos into line items since day one.
Field crew’s idea of multitasking: hammering while telling jokes.
Client: 'Can it be ready by Friday?' Contractor: 'Depends which Friday you mean.'
Why was the concrete always calm? It knew how to set its priorities.
Estimators: proof that numbers can be funny if you squint hard enough.
Field motto: Measure, sweat, repeat.
Client: 'We want it stylish.' Contractor: 'Stylish for your budget? That’s a challenge.'
Why do builders love elevators? Because they always lift their spirits.
Estimators’ coffee consumption is directly proportional to project complexity.
Field life wisdom: If it wobbles, brace it; if it falls, call it modern art.
Client: 'Can we make it simple?' Contractor: 'Yes, but the bill will be complicated.'
Why did the crane blush? It was caught lifting feelings instead of beams.
Estimators: the only people who can make numbers weep with laughter.
Field workers’ favorite motivational quote: 'Measure twice, swear once.'
Client: 'Can we reduce the cost?' Contractor: 'Sure, reduce the quality too.'
Why do builders tell jokes at lunch? To keep things from cracking.
Estimators: turning caffeine into precise calculations.
Field life: the art of balancing tools, coffee, and patience.
Client: 'We want fast delivery.' Contractor: 'Fast, expensive, or both? Choose one.'
Why did the blueprint take a nap? It needed some space to plan.
Estimators: the only people who laugh at spreadsheets for fun.
Field workers’ motto: Screw it in, tighten it later.
Client: 'Can we add another floor?' Contractor: 'Sure, but the elevator bill comes extra.'
Why did the concrete mixer get promoted? It always stirred things up.
Estimators’ favorite song: 'Money, Money, Money'.
Field life wisdom: If the tape measure fits, it ships.
Client: 'We want it unique.' Contractor: 'Unique is just another word for expensive.'
Why did the builder go to art school? To learn how to draw conclusions.
Estimators’ secret talent: predicting costs before coffee.
Field motto: Hard hat, big heart, bigger laughs.
Client: 'Can we get a discount?' Contractor: 'Sure, after the next apocalypse.'
Why did the crane join a band? It had great lifting notes.
Estimators’ guide: Always round up — in math and caffeine.
Field life reality: Coffee before concrete.
Client: 'Can you make it bigger and faster?' Contractor: 'Yes, but only in your imagination.'
Why did the hammer look sad? It was feeling nailed down.
Estimators: the only people who celebrate when numbers align.
Field crew’s survival kit: Gloves, helmet, and a sense of humor.
Client: 'Can we skip the approvals?' Contractor: 'Sure, enjoy the chaos.'
Why do builders love elevators? It raises their spirits.
Estimators’ morning mantra: Coffee first, chaos second.
Field motto: Drill it, fill it, smile about it.
Client: 'We want it fast and cheap.' Contractor: 'Pick one.'
Why did the blueprint blush? It was being examined.
Estimators: making spreadsheets look thrilling since forever.
Field life wisdom: Hammer in hand, laughter in heart.
Client: 'Can we finish by Friday?' Contractor: 'Depends on which Friday.'
